Description: Body sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glaze (fired red); part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centres; below, two bands in white; exterior: painted decoration consisting possibly of a seated lion or sphinx to right (part of rump and tail remaining); part of spiked rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 79, NAU25), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Chios. The sample number is written in ink 'NAU 25' on break. For parallels regarding the seated figure, see Lemos 1991, pl. 84, no. 648 from Aegina.
Bibliographic references: Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (78-9, p. 82-3, fig. 2) (NAU 25)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0618) (phase 2)
